case_vignette: A 75-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of sharp, stabbing pain in the lower back that radiates to the back of his left leg. He also has had a loss of sensitivity around his buttocks and inner thighs as well as increased trouble urinating the last week. Two years ago, he was diagnosed with prostate cancer and was treated with radiation therapy. Neurologic examination shows reduced strength and reflexes in the left lower extremity; the right side is normal. The resting anal sphincter tone is normal but the squeeze tone is reduced.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having sharp, stabbing pain in my lower back that shoots down to the back of my left leg for the past two weeks.

Thank you for sharing that information. Based on what you've told me, I would like to ask a few more questions to help narrow down the possible causes of your symptoms.

Can you tell me, have you experienced any other symptoms such as weakness, numbness, or tingling in your legs or feet? And have you noticed any changes in your balance or coordination?

Thank you for sharing that information. Based on what you've told me, I would like to consider the possibility of a neurological condition such as a stroke or a neurodegenerative disorder.

Can you tell me, have you experienced any sudden or unexpected weakness or numbness in your left leg or any other part of your body? And have you noticed any changes in your speech, language, or cognitive function?
I haven't had any sudden weakness or numbness, changes in my speech, language, or cognitive function.

Great, that helps to narrow it down. Based on what you've told me, I would like to consider the possibility of a peripheral neuropathy, which is a condition that affects the nerves outside of the brain and spinal cord.

Can you tell me, have you noticed any changes in your sensation, such as numbness, tingling, or burning, in your left leg or any other part of your body? And have you experienced any pain or discomfort in your left leg?
Yes, there's been a loss of sensitivity around my buttocks and inner thighs, and I've been having sharp, stabbing pain in my left leg.

Thank you for providing more information. Based on what you've told me, I would like to consider the possibility of a nerve root compression or sciatica. This is a common condition that occurs when the nerve roots that run down the spine become compressed or irritated, often due to a herniated disc or spinal stenosis.

Can you tell me, have you experienced any weakness or numbness in your left leg, or any difficulty controlling your bladder or bowels? And have you noticed any improvement in your symptoms after resting or changing positions?

Thank you for sharing that information. Based on what you've told me, I would like to consider the possibility of a lumbar spine injury or condition, such as a herniated disc or spinal stenosis, which can cause nerve root compression and lead to symptoms such as weakness, numbness, and pain in the legs.

Thank you for letting me know. Based on what you've told me, I would like to consider the possibility of a lumbar spine structural condition, such as a herniated disc or spinal stenosis, which can cause nerve root compression and lead to symptoms such as weakness, numbness, and pain in the legs.

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?

I've been experiencing sharp, stabbing pain in my lower back that spreads to the back of my left leg, and I've also noticed I've lost some feeling around my buttocks and inner thighs. Additionally, I'm having increased trouble urinating lately.

Thank you for sharing this information. Based on what you've told me, I would like to ask a few more questions to help narrow down the possible causes of your symptoms.

Can you tell me your age and gender? And have you noticed any recent changes in your lifestyle or activities that could be contributing to your symptoms?
I am a 75-year-old man, and no, I haven't made any recent changes in my lifestyle or activities.

Great, thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms, I would like to ask some questions about your medical history.

Have you had any previous surgeries or illnesses, especially related to your back or legs? And have you noticed any similar symptoms in the past, such as numbness or weakness in your legs?
Two years ago, I was diagnosed with prostate cancer and received radiation therapy. I haven't had any surgeries related to my back or legs, nor have I noticed similar symptoms in the past.

Thank you for sharing that information. Based on your history of prostate cancer and radiation therapy, as well as your current symptoms, I would like to consider the possibility of radiation-induced neuropathy.

Can you tell me more about the radiation therapy you received? How long ago did you receive it, and how many treatments did you have? And have you experienced any other symptoms related to the radiation therapy, such as fatigue or skin changes?

I received radiation therapy for my prostate cancer two years ago, but I can't recall how many treatments I had. Aside from my current symptoms, I haven't noticed any other issues like fatigue or skin changes.

Thank you for letting me know. Based on your history of radiation therapy and the symptoms you're experiencing, I would like to consider the possibility of radiation-induced plexopathy.

Can you tell me more about the location of the numbness or tingling you're experiencing? Is it limited to one area, or is it more widespread? And have you noticed any weakness or loss of coordination in your legs or feet?
The numbness is around my buttocks and inner thighs, and recently, I have noticed reduced strength in my left leg.

Thank you for providing more information. Based on your symptoms, I would like to consider the possibility of a radiation-induced plexopathy, as you suspected.

Can you tell me more about your radiation therapy? What was the radiation dose and field size, and how long ago did you complete treatment? And have you experienced any other symptoms related to radiation therapy, such as fatigue or skin changes?

I'm sorry, but I don't know the specific details about the radiation dose and field size. I completed the treatment two years ago and haven't experienced any other symptoms like fatigue or skin changes since then.

No worries, thank you for letting me know. Based on your history of radiation therapy two years ago, and the symptoms you're experiencing now, I would like to consider the possibility of a radiation-induced plexopathy.

Can you tell me more about the location of the numbness or tingling you're experiencing? Is it limited to one area, or is it more widespread? And have you noticed any other symptoms such as weakness or loss of coordination in your legs or feet?

Also, have you had any recent illnesses or infections that could be contributing to your symptoms? Any new medications or supplements you're taking that could be causing numbness or tingling?
The numbness is focused around my buttocks and inner thighs, and I've noticed weakness in my left leg, but no new illnesses, medications, or supplements recently.

Thank you for providing more information. Based on your symptoms, I would like to consider the possibility of a radiation-induced plexopathy.

A radiation-induced plexopathy is a condition where the nerves in the pelvic area are damaged due to radiation therapy. This can cause numbness, tingling, and weakness in the affected area, which in your case is around the buttocks and inner thighs.

I would recommend a neurological examination to confirm the diagnosis and rule out other potential causes of your symptoms. This may involve tests such as an EMG (electromyography) or an NCS (nerve conduction study) to assess the function of the nerves in your legs.

In the meantime, I would advise you to avoid any strenuous activities that may exacerbate the symptoms and to keep a log of your symptoms to track their progression.

Please let me know if you have any questions or concerns, and we can discuss further.

Thank you for providing more information. Based on your symptoms, it is possible that you may have a herniated disc in your lower back that is causing the weakness and numbness in your left leg, as well as the sharp pain that shoots down to the back of your leg.

A herniated disc occurs when the soft, gel-like center of a spinal disc bulges out through a tear in the outer, tougher layer. This can put pressure on the nearby nerves, causing pain, numbness, and weakness in the affected area.

It is important to seek medical attention if you are experiencing these types of symptoms, as herniated discs can cause permanent nerve damage if left untreated. A healthcare professional can perform a thorough examination and imaging tests, such as an MRI, to confirm the diagnosis and develop an appropriate treatment plan.

In the meantime, you can try some self-care measures to help manage your symptoms. These include:

* Taking over-the-counter pain medications, such as ibuprofen or acetaminophen, as directed
*

The patient has not reported any recent illnesses or infections, changes in travel or lifestyle, or changes in posture or gait.
